reviewText:
LEGO® Pirates of the Caribbean: The Video Game

That was my first go at a Lego game! And to be honest I thoroughly enjoyed it.

You have to collect the Lego coins to become a true pirate at the end of each level’s but also do not forget to collect other important items.

I personally did not have issue with the game freezing or not saving (the game save automatically at the end of each level).

The Positive:

•	Plenty of characters to unlock
•	Good replay ability
•	Great cut scenes with good humour
•	Nice levels

The Negative:

•	Very short game in story mode (I finished under 4 hours)

Overall, it’s a fun and easy game to play. And if you like me, you will probably be hooked and rush to buy other games from the franchise.

MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HERE

FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

reviewText: Honestly I don't know why the reviews for this are Mixed. It's no different to other Lego games in its mechanics - smash stuff to collect studs with which to buy other characters and such. Hidden throughout levels are minikits, same as every other game. What makes this one different for me is the fighting. In other Lego games it's kinda a case of mash the attack button until you win
date:
but in this one you can time it so you can block as well, and there's sometimes a nice back and forth which gives it a really fun swashbuckling feel, as you'd expect and hope for in a pirate game.

The style of narrative is the same as other games too, told in a slapstick silent-movie style. This really helps to explain the third and fourth movies to me, since I couldn't follow them at all compared to the first two. Also there are no forced speeches to break up the flow ^.^

So if you like Lego games as a concept, you'll probably enjoy this. The music is great, the combat is fun, the levels are well designed and fun to smash through.. I just really like this game ^.^

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of LEGO games and I've played many of them: after completing this to 100% I fell like Pirates of the Carribean is one of the best in the entire series.

- many interesting levels (beaches, cities, prisons, mountains... there's a very various amount of level types)
- LOTS of different characters\powers\skills
- free of bugs
- you get to ride crabs and use goats to pull orange bars

CONS:
- no acting voices so if you haven't watched the movies you probably won't understand the whole story

reviewText: When I first bought this game, I was skeptical if it would be as good as Lego Batman or Lego Star Wars, but now that I've gotten into the game more I can say it's actually my favorite Lego game yet. The graphics have improved a lot, the cutscenes are longer and actually have much more entertaining humor, plus they are more relevant to the movies. In the beginning, I was skeptical since the first few missions aren't that great and the formatting seemed a little different, but once I got into it, it quickly became very entertaining.  I have never encountered any technical problems or bugs whatsoever, so I would be skeptical about believing some of the other, more negative reviews in that regard. All in all, I'd give it an 8.5/10. I highly recommend this game and think it has made some very good changes from past games such as the new sword combat, but the only real negatives I can think of are the fact that they cut vehicle missions and that there are only 5 levels per movie instead of 6.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the Lego Travller's Tales games and I've played them all (except for the Lego City one on Wii) either on PC or console. LEGO® Pirates of the Caribbean: The Video Game takes some of my favorite movie content and applies it to the fun formula that is used in these types of games.

So is it worth it? Well yes, but if you're as big a fan of the POTC series as I am, you might find yourself a bit dissappointed. My biggest dissappointment with the game was the lack of Hans Zimmer's great score, which is an essential part of the success of the movies. You'll find many recognizable tracks such as Jack Sparrow" and "The Kraken" but much of the score is missing and instead is replaced with mediocre music that doesn't compliment Zimmer's score. Why? Well I have two guesses:

1. The creators of the game did not believe the music would fit with the pace of the levels they designed. If this is true
date: I completely disagree with their decision.\n\n2.  Because the game is using Disney intellectual property
recommended:
obtaining the rights to the music was expensive for Travller's Tales. I find this the more probable case.



My other problem with the game is that it's buggy. I haven't experienced the crashes that other people have
hoursPlayed: but I have encountered annoying bugs. The most annoying takes place on the last level
voteText: where an event doesn't take place as it's supposed to and you're pretty much stuck. The only way to beat the level is to restart and go through the whole thing
helpfulPercent:
hoping it doesn't bug out again. I've encountered this bug on both the PC and console versions.


So would I recommend the game? Well despite the minor bugs and the lack of Zimmer's score
votesHelpful: I would say yes. It's a fun game that uses familiar lego mechanics and captures the spirit of the movies. If you're a fan of TT lego games or the POTC movies

reviewText:
Recommended for:
LEGO Traveller's Tales fans.
People who have seen the movies.
Completionists.

Pros:
- Good, friendly humor in the spirit of the movies appropiate for young and old.
- Interesting story level design, albeit with repetition (if you've seen one sailboat)
- excellent animations. Your character Captain (!) Jack Sparrow sometimes fights dirty during a swordfight and smashes a bottle on your opponent's head or slips a banana under his feet.

Contras:
- Story cutscenes make nearly no sense if you haven't seen the movies.
- Hublevel not as big as in the later Tt games (Well, it's one of their older games, so no biggie).
- Unimaginative mini-boss fights.
- Acrobatic sequences and walking narrow paths over abysses and poisonous swamps get frustrating very fast due to lack of precision and static perspective (using XBOX-Controller). Seems to be the crux in all LEGO Tt games. Ditto gamebreaking glitches, when script sequences and/or NPC get stuck, so that you have to reload the level to proceed beyond.


All in all LEGO PotC is only mediocre as far as Traveller's Tales LEGO games concerned.
LEGO Harry Potter and LEGO Jurassic World are better. Go play these!

reviewText:
Back in days,i decided to buy 3 Lego Games. I took Pirates of Caribbean,Hobbit and Marvel Heroes. First i decided to try Pirates of Caribbean since it's one of my favourite movies.

This game have nice grafic,funny gameplay and interesting puzzles - and that's mostly everything pozitive i can say about it.

After cca 30 minutes-1 hour of playing,game will crash to desktop without any error message. It's not only ,many other people suffer from constant crashes-and there is no any patches that would've fix it,what's pretty lame for a game that carry ''LEGO'' in it's name.
There's also no any tutorial,it took pretty while to catch how to play.
There is also no any voice actors in this game.

Skip this game,any buy any other Lego game. I tried Hobbit after this failure,it's thousand times better,and of course,there are no any bugs,glitches or crashes in Lego Hobbit.

reviewText:
Another fun LEGO game. I like the style of these older LEGO games where there are no voiceovers, just random sound effects, grunts, and slapstick comedy to tell the story (not that there really was much of one past the first pirates movie).

The hub world is small compared to the newer LEGO games like Lord of the Rings, Hobbit, or Marvel Super Heroes, but still has a fair share of hidden secrets (and the all-important cheats, represented by red hats in this game).

If you're a fan of LEGO games or pirates of the carribean, I highly recommend this game (on sale naturally, although $20 isn't bad for the amount of content).

There is also no any voice actors in this game.

Skip this game,any buy any other Lego game. I tried Hobbit after this failure,it's thousand times better,and of course,there are no any bugs,glitches or crashes in Lego Hobbit.

reviewText:
LEGO Pirates of the Carribean is another title in the LEGO series by Traveler's Tales. It tells the tale which spans accross the entire franchise (at the date writing this review) in a fun, cheeky and childish way which is friendly to everybody.

It features the same engine and core mechanics as many other LEGO titles in the series, but it is obviously a much earlier version. It lacks the story telling components introduced in later releases and it does depend on the user to know the story well before actually playing. It attempts to present itself in a way which does sufficiently tell the story, but without prior knowledge it still has unfinished links in this translation.

There are various bugs in this game which are both infuriating and game-breaking. Quite often you'll be able to jump into a spot with no way of escaping other than restarting the game, and some technical issues causing crashes. Limiting the framefrate to less than 60 seems to fix those problems though. On top of all the problems with this game, I really enjoyed the franchise specific animations and the swordplay mechanics, especially later in teh game.

Overall it's a great game which you can have a lot of fun with the franchise and LEGO. If you're able to iron out the frustrating parts, it's definitely worth the time and I would recommend it.

reviewText: Picked this up for £3 in a sale just for a laugh and it turned out to be £3 well spent. It's so much fun. It manages to follow the story of all 4 movies perfectly while doing everything that a Lego game should do. The best part however is the amount of laughs you'll have. Despite having no words in the game at all it nails the humour of the movies, especially with Captain Jack Sparrow who is easily the best character.\n\nThis game is definitely worth a buy when you get a chance, especially when it's on sale. :)
